Title: Compromise of Bayer Pharmaceuticals
Affiliations: Wicked Panda
Description: A threat actor put malicious software on Bayer's computer system but did not steal any information, as reported by the company.

Title: Cyber espionage by the United Arab Emirates (UAE)
Affiliations: Believed to be the work of the UAE government.
Description: Former U.S. government intelligence operatives working for the UAE used the spying tool Karma to hack the iPhones of activists, diplomats, and rival foreign leaders.

Title: Operation Soft Cell
Affiliations: APT 10
Description: This threat actor hacked global telecommunications companies for personal data of government officials, activists, and dissidents of interest to Beijing.

Title: Targeting of U.S. and European think tanks
Affiliations: Believed to be the work of Fancy Bear.
Description: Hackers set up fake login pages or sent spoof e-mails to people who work with the think tanks in an attempt to trick them into handing over information, such as passwords.
Victims: Center for Strategic and International Studies, German Council on Foreign Relations, The Aspen Institutes in Europe, The German Marshall Fund

Title: Attack on Iranian computer systems
Affiliations: U.S. Cyber Command
Description: U.S. Cyber Command hacked Iranian rocket and missile launch systems in retaliation for the downing of a U.S. drone and attacks on oil tankers in the Strait of Hormuz. Iranian officials said the attack was not successful.
Victims: Iranian rocket and missile launch systems

Title: Targeting of Visma
Affiliations: Believed to be the work of APT 10.
Description: Hackers used malware from the dark web to target a Norwegian internet service provider. The goal of the attack was to gain access to customers’ intellectual property, strategic plans, and emails.

Title: Compromise of Yandex
Affiliations: Five Eyes
Description: This threat actor deployed Regin, a rare type of malware, in an attempt to spy on user accounts for Yandex, a Russian search engine and email provider.
Sponsor: United States, Australia, Canada, New Zealand, United Kingdom

Title: U.S. Cyber Command offensive attack of Russian troll farm
Affiliations: U.S. Cyber Command
Description: In November 2018, the U.S. Cyber Command launched an offensive campaign to combat a Russian troll operation known for using disinformation tactics.

Title: Attacks on private U.S. companies
Affiliations: Iran
Description: This threat actor increased malicious activity targeting U.S. companies following a U.S. attack on Iranian computer systems.

Title: Targeting of universities' maritime military secrets
Affiliations: Believed to be the work of Leviathan.
Description: Chinese hackers targeted twenty-seven universities in the United States, Canada, and Southeast Asia as part of a scheme to steal research about maritime technology under development for military use.
Victims: University of Hawaii, University of Washington, Massachusetts Institute of Technology , Pennsylvania State University, Duke University

Title: Whitefly
Affiliations: Believed to be behind the Singapore health-care breach in July 2018.
Description: This threat actor has been active since mid-2017, targeting mainly health-care, media, telecommunications, and engineering organizations in Singapore, in addition to multinational companies with a presence in the country. The group has also targeted defense, telecommunications, and energy companies in Russia, the United Kingdom, and Southeast Asia. The group relies on a combination of custom malware, open-source hacking tools, and legitimate applications to achieve its goals.

Title: 2019 Indonesian elections
Affiliations: Believed to be the work of Russian and Chinese hackers.
Description: Senior Indonesian election officials accused Chinese and Russian hackers of manipulating and modifying Indonesia's voter data base to disrupt the presidential elections.

Title: Chinese intelligence repurposed NSA tools to attack private companies
Affiliations: APT 3
Description: The threat actor repurposed hacking tools used against them by the U.S. National Security Agency (NSA) to attack private companies in Asia and Europe. These attacks went undetected for two years.
Victims: Belgium, Luxembourg, The Philippines, and Vietnam

Title: Global hijacking of domain name system (DNS)
Affiliations: Suspected to be the work of Iranian actors.
Description: An unknown actor with a connection to Iran hijacked DNS records to target the traffic of governments and telecommunications organizations around the world.
Victims: United States, South Korea, Canada, Lebanon , United Arab Emirates

Title: Compromise of Amnesty International Hong Kong
Affiliations: APTs associated with Beijing
Description: This threat actor compromised Amnesty International Hong Kong's system to steal the personal information of supporters.

Title: Attempted attack on the Democratic National Convention (DNC) during 2018 elections
Affiliations: Suspected to be the work of the Dukes.
Description: The DNC alleged it was targeted in an unsuccessful cyberattack eight days after the 2018 elections in an attempted spear-phishing campaign.

Title: Compromise of British infrastructure
Affiliations: Iranian Revolutionary Guard
Description: A threat actor compromised the British Post Office and local government networks, stealing personal data—including email addresses and mobile phone numbers—of thousands of employees.
Victims: British Post Office and local government networks

Title: Attempted attack on the Democratic National Convention (DNC) during 2018 elections
Affiliations: Suspected to be the work of the Dukes.
Description: The DNC alleged it was targeted in an unsuccessful cyberattack eight days after the 2018 elections in an attempted spear-phishing campaign.

Title: UK targeting of the Islamic State group
Affiliations: Believed to be associated with the U.S. targeting of the Islamic State Group.
Description: The United Kingdom’s Government Communications Headquarters director announced that, along with the UK Ministry of Defense, it had conducted a “major offensive cyber campaign” directed at the Islamic State, with the purpose of disrupting the group’s ability to recruit and coordinate. The UK campaign mirrors a previous one announced by the U.S. government in 2016.

Title: Targeting of Westinghouse Electric Corporation
Affiliations: Believed to be the work of APT 28
Description: A threat actor targeted Westinghouse Electric Company, a nuclear power developer, for espionage purposes. One of the individuals alleged to be behind this incident, believed to be Russian military intelligence (known as GRU), was indicted by the U.S. Justice Department.

Title: Targeting of North Korean defectors and journalists
Affiliations: Believed to be associated with the Lazarus Group
Description: A threat actor targets North Korean defectors and journalists with an interest in North Korea by compromising their Android devices, for espionage.

Title: Raspite
Description: This threat actor targets entities that operate industrial control systems in the electric utility sector.

Title: Attempt to compromise Ukraine's judicial system
Affiliations: Believed to be the work of a Russian hacking group.
Description: Ukraine’s security agency thwarted an attack attempting to target the country’s court system.

Title: APT 37
Affiliations: Also known as Reaper and Group 123
Description: This threat actor uses social engineering techniques to target companies in the chemicals, electronics, manufacturing, aerospace, automotive, and health-care sectors, as well as the South Korean government.

Title: Targeting of German critical infrastructure sectors
Affiliations: Believed to be the work of Crouching Yeti
Description: A threat actor targeted critical infrastructure entities in the energy, water, and telecommunications sectors, prompting the German government to issue a public alert. In remarks following the alert's release, the head of Germany’s domestic intelligence agency accused Russia of controlling the targeting campaign.

Title: Targeting of Omar Abdulaziz
Description: A threat actor targeted the iPhone of Omar Abdulaziz, a critic of the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia living in Canada, for espionage purposes. The threat actor uses the Pegasus tool, created by the NSO Group.

Title: Compromise of Mongolian government data center
Description: A threat actor has compromised a government data center in Mongolia. Kaspersky Lab assesses that the threat actor used its access to compromise websites that they will use in subsequent watering-hole attacks.

Title: Alleged Russian compromise of networking equipment
Affiliations: Believed to be associated with the Black Energy threat actor. Also known as VPNFilter
Description: The U.S. Department of Homeland Security and the UK National Cyber Security Centre issued a joint alert warning of a Russian state-sponsored campaign to compromise networking equipment, such as routers and switches, to support their cyber operations. A few weeks later, the FBI took control of a botnet with over five hundred thousand compromised devices and issued a public request that individuals with certain router models restart them.
Victims: Worldwide, United States, United Kingdom, Ukraine

Title: Gorgon Group
Description: This threat actor targets government entities in the United States and Europe. It also conducts criminal operations.
Victims: United States, Spain, Russian Federation, United Kingdom

Title: Targeting of the Parliament of Australia
Affiliations: Unknown
Description: An attack targeted computer systems in both houses of the Parliament of Australia. The systems of the ruling Liberal-National Coalition Party and Labor, the main opposition party, were compromised, but there is no evidence of electoral interference.

Title: Compromise of an air-gapped German government network
Description: A threat actor compromised the Informationsverbund Berlin-Bonn, a computer network air gapped from the global internet, used by the German chancellery, parliament, Foreign Office, and other government departments based in Bonn, Germany.

Title: RedAlpha
Affiliations: Believed to use similar infrastructure as the NetTraveler, Icefog, and APT 17 threat actors
Description: This threat actor targets Tibetan organizations based in India, for the purpose of espionage.

Title: Targeting of congressional campaigns for the 2018 U.S. midterm elections
Affiliations: Believed to be the work of APT 28
Description: A threat actor targets the campaigns of candidates running for Congress in the 2018 U.S. midterm elections.

Title: Targeting of South Korean actors prior to meeting of Donald J. Trump and Kim Jong-un
Affiliations: Believed to be the work of TempTick and Turla
Description: Two separate threat actors targeted South Korean government organizations prior to the meeting between U.S. President Donald J. Trump and North Korean leader Kim Jong-un, for the purpose of espionage.

Title: Indictment of officials from the Mabna Institute
Description: The U.S. Department of Justice indicted nine officials from the Mabna Insititute, an Iranian company alleged to have conducted state-sponsored cyber operations on behalf of the Iranian Revolutionary Guards. They are alleged to have compromised the networks of over 144 U.S. universities, 176 universities in over twenty-one other countries, as well as private sector, government, and multilateral entities.
Victims: United States, United Nations, UNICEF, Australia, Canada, China, Denmark, Germany, Ireland, Israel, Italy, Japan, Malaysia, Netherlands, Norway, Poland, Singapore, Republic of Korea, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey, United Kingdom

Title: Rancor
Affiliations: Believed to use similar tools as DragonOK
Description: This threat actor uses spear-phishing techniques to target political organizations in Southeast Asia, for the purpose of espionage.

Title: Targeting of Yahya Assiri
Description: A threat actor targeted Yahya Assiri, a critic of the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia and a researcher at Amnesty International, for espionage purposes. The threat actor used the Pegasus tool, created by the NSO Group.

Title: Compromise of SingHealth, a large health-care provider in Singapore
Affiliations: Believed to be the work of Whitefly.
Description: A threat actor compromises the networks of SingHealth, the largest health-care provider in Singapore. Personal data of over 1.5 million patients was compromised, including the pharmaceutical prescriptions of 160,000 people.

Title: TempTick
Affiliations: Believed to be responsible for the targeting of South Korean actors prior to the meeting of Donald J. Trump and Kim Jong-un.
Description: This threat actor targets organizations in the finance, defense, aerospace, technology, health-care, and automotive sectors and media organizations in East Asia for the purpose of espionage. This threat actor is also known for targeting a South Korean company that produces USB sticks generally used to transfer data to air-gapped networks.

Title: Targeting of organizations associated with trade activity with China
Description: A threat actor is targeting multiple organizations with trade ties to China, including those connected with China’s Belt and Road Initiative. The actor also targets organizations in advance of officials’ meetings with Chinese trade officials.

Title: APT 39
Affiliations: Believed to be connected to the Iranian government.
Description: This threat actor, operating since November 2014, focuses on the Middle East. It mainly targets the telecommunications industry, and also targets the travel industry and supporting IT firms, and the high-tech industry.
Victims: Saudi Arabia, Egypt, Turkey, Iraq, Spain, Norway, Australia, South Korea

Title: Targeting of foreign ministries
Affiliations: Believed to be the work of APT 28
Description: A threat actor targeted a foreign ministry in Europe and in North America using spear-phishing techniques for the purpose of espionage.

Title: Operation Parliament
Description: This threat actor uses spear-phishing techniques to target parliaments, government ministries, academics, and media organizations, primarily in the Middle East, for the purpose of espionage.
Victims: Palestine, Egypt, Jordan, United Arab Emirates, Saudi Arabia, Djibouti, Qatar, Chile, Lebonon, Somalia, Iraq, Morocco, Syria, India, Iran, Canada, United States, United Kingdom, Germany, Israel, Afghanistan, Serbia, Russia, Oman, Kuwait, South Korea, Denmark

Title: Operation GhostSecret
Affiliations: Believed to be the work of the Lazarus Group
Description: A threat actor targets critical infrastructure and organizations in the entertainment, finance, health-care, education, and telecommunications sectors.
Victims: United States, United Kingdom, India, Thailand, Guatemala, Germany, France, Canada, Brazil, China, Bangladesh, Thailand, Hong Kong, Japan, Australia,

Title: Compromise of the German Foreign Office
Affiliations: Believed to be the work of Turla
Description: A threat actor has compromised the German Foreign Office, for the purpose of espionage.

Title: Targeting of U.S. Navy contractors
Affiliations: Believed to be the work of APT 10.
Description: In a series of incidents, Chinese hackers breached U.S. Navy contractors’ systems to steal information including ship maintenance data and missile plans.

Title: Targeting of a European defense agency
Affiliations: Believed to be the work of APT 28
Description: A threat actor targeted a European defense agency with a spear-phishing email, which only deploys a payload if the victim opens an email attachment and scrolls to page 3.

Title: Inception Framework
Description: This threat actor uses spear-phishing techniques to target private-sector energy, defense, aerospace, research, and media organizations and embassies in Africa, Europe, and the Middle East, for the purpose of espionage.
Victims: South Africa, Kenya, United Kingdom, Malaysia, Suriname

Title: Targeting of Japanese companies
Affiliations: Believed to be the work of APT 10
Description: This threat actor targets Japanese media and defense companies for espionage purposes.

Title: Winnti Umbrella
Affiliations: Believed to be associated with the Axiom, APT 17, and Mirage threat actors. Believed to share the same tools and infrastructure as the threat actors that carried out Operation Aurora, the 2015 targeting of video game companies, the 2015 targeting of the Thai government, and the 2017 targeting of Chinese-language news websites
Description: This threat actor targets software companies and political organizations in the United States, China, Japan, and South Korea. It primarily acts to support cyber operations conducted by other threat actors affiliated with Chinese intelligence services.
Victims: United States, United Kingdom, Japan, South Korea, China

Title: Chrysene
Affiliations: Believed to be linked to the compromise of Saudi Aramco, malware Shamoon 2.0, and the OilRig threat actor
Description: This threat actor targets organizations involved in oil, gas, and electricity production, primarily in the Gulf region, for espionage purposes. According to one cybersecurity company, the threat actor “compromises a target machine and passes it off to another threat actor for further exploitation.”

Title: Global bank attacks
Affiliations: Suspected to be the work of the Lazarus Group.
Description: A North Korean group is believed to have stolen hundreds of millions of dollars by infiltrating the computer systems of banks around the world since 2014.
Victims: United States, Mexico, Chile, Brazil, Uruguay, Poland, Turkey, Bangladesh, Malaysia, Vietnam, Russia, Phillipines, Taiwan

Title: Compromise of American aerospace companies
Affiliations: China's Jiangsu Ministry of State Security
Description: This threat actor reportedly intruded into American aerospace companies' computer systems to steal intellectual property and business information, including information related to turbofan engines used in commercial aircraft.
Victims: Aerospace companies based in Arizona, Massachusetts, and Oregon

Title: Targeting of international sports federations
Affiliations: Believed to be the work of APT 28
Description: A threat actor targeted international sports organizations in Western Europe in the run-up to the International Olympic Committee’s banning Russian athletes from participating in the 2018 Winter Olympics in South Korea.
Victims: European Ice Hockey Federation, International Ski Federation, International Biathlon Union, International Bobsleigh and Skeleton Federation, International Luge Federation

Title: Compromise of a U.S. Navy contractor
Description: A threat actor compromises the networks of a contractor for the U.S. Navy, exfiltrating 614 gigabytes of sensitive information, including data related to a new U.S. anti-ship missile and submarine communications systems.

Title: Targeting of AMC Theatres
Affiliations: Believed to be the work of Lazarus Group
Description: A threat actor targeted U.S. movie theater chain AMC Theatres in 2014 using spear-phishing techniques. The U.S. Department of Justice alleges that the incident was related to the chain's screenings of The Interview, a movie depicting the assassination of North Korean leader Kim Jong-un.

Title: Compromise of the EU's diplomatic communication network
Affiliations: Suspected to be the work of Chinese military hackers.
Description: Hackers have infiltrated the EU’s diplomatic communication network for years, using phishing attacks to steal sensitive documents related to trade negotiations and meetings with foreign leaders.
Victims: European Union, United Nations, American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations

Title: Targeting of global financial organizations and bitcoin users
Affiliations: Believed to be the work of the Lazarus Group
Description: A threat actor targeted financial organizations and bitcoin users, for the purpose of identifying individuals with bitcoin wallets.

Title: Compromise of Cambodian election organizations
Affiliations: Believed to be the work of Leviathan
Description: A threat actor compromises opposition parties, as well as organizations charged with overseeing the 2018 Cambodian elections, for espionage purposes.

Title: Targeting of the Organization for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons
Affiliations: Believed to be the work of APT 28
Description: A threat actor, believed to be Russian military intelligence, targeted the office of the Organization for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons in The Hague with a view of compromising its Wi-Fi network for espionage purposes. Dutch authorities were able to foil the operation, and in a joint press conference with UK officials publicly identified four suspected Russian intelligence officers involved. The United States, Australia, Canada, and New Zealand issued statements denouncing Russia's cyber operations.
Victims: Organization for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons

Title: Covellite
Affiliations: Believed to use similar tools as the Lazarus Group
Description: This threat actor compromises the networks of companies involved in electric power, specifically looking for intellectual property and information about the companies’ operations.

Title: Targeting of Austal
Affiliations: Unknown
Description: Austal, a major Australian defense contractor and shipbuilder, was targeted in a data breach. Hackers gained access to ship designs and personnel contact information.

Title: Compromise of Managed Service Providers and technology companies
Affiliations: China's Tianjin State Security Bureau
Description: The threat actor compromised eight technology service providers, including Hewlett Packard Enterprise and IBM (their cloud services in particular were targeted), to steal commercial secrets from over forty-five client technology companies. The victims include Swedish telecom giant Ericsson, U.S. Navy shipbuilder Huntington Ingalls Industries, and travel reservation system Sabre.
Victims: Networks and clients of Hewlett Packard Enterprise, IBM, Fujitsu, Tata Consultancy Services, NTT Data, Dimension Data, Computer Sciences Corporation, and DXC Technology

Title: Targeting of U.S. energy and other critical infrastructure sectors
Affiliations: Believed to be linked to the Crouching Yeti threat actor
Description: A threat actor that the U.S. government believes to be sponsored by the Russian government, targets entities in the U.S. energy, nuclear power, water, aviation, and critical manufacturing sectors. According to the Department of Homeland Security, this activity has been ongoing since at least 2014.

Title: Targeting of Mammoth Screen
Affiliations: Believed to be the work of Lazarus Group
Description: A threat actor targeted Mammoth Screen, a UK production company that produced Opposite Number, a television drama set in North Korea.

Title: Attack on Italian oil firm Saipem
Affiliations: Possibly linked to an Iran-based group that uses the Shamoon virus to target oil and gas entities with a connection to Saudi Arabia.
Description: An attack on the Italian oil firm Saipem targeted servers based in India, Kuwait, Saudi Arabia, Scotland, and the United Arab Emirates. Hackers used a variant of the Shamoon virus.

Title: Targeting of consulates and embassies in Eastern Europe
Affiliations: Believed to be the work of Turla
Description: A threat actor targeted consulates and embassies in Eastern Europe for the purpose of espionage.

Title: Mythic Leopard
Affiliations: Also known as Transparent Tribe and C-Major
Description: This threat actor uses social engineering and spear phishing to target military and defense organizations in India, for the purpose of espionage.

Title: Compromise of the U.S. Anti-Doping Agency
Affiliations: Believed to be the work of APT 28
Description: A threat actor compromised the U.S. Anti-Doping Agency. Seven of the individuals alleged to be behind this incident, believed to be Russian military intelligence (known as GRU), were indicted by the U.S. Justice Department.

Title: Dymalloy
Affiliations: Believed to be linked to Crouching Yeti
Description: This threat actor targets industrial control systems in Turkey, Europe, and North America.

Title: Compromise of Ukrainian government
Affiliations: Believed to be the work of Gamaredon.
Description: A Russian actor tied to Russia’s Federal Security Service (FSB) targeted Ukrainian government agencies with a backdoor attacker called Pterodo before and during Russia’s seizure of Ukrainian vessels.

Title: Targeting of individuals of interest to the government of Lebanon
Description: A threat actor used a tool, Dark Caracal, to target military personnel, activists, journalists, and lawyers for espionage purposes.
Victims: United States, Canada, Germany, Lebanon, France

Title: Compromise of a diplomatic entity in Qatar
Description: A threat actor uses a zero-day vulnerability in Adobe Flash software to compromise a diplomatic target in Qatar.

Title: Targeting of U.S. defense contractors
Affiliations: Believed to be the work of Lazarus Group
Description: A threat actor targeted the networks of Lockheed Martin, a U.S. defense contractor. It is one of the developers of the Terminal High Altitude Area Defense (THAAD) system installed in South Korea.

Title: Compromise of South Korean resettlement agency
Affiliations: Suspected to be the work of North Korean authorities.
Description: The personal information of nearly one thousand North Koreans who defected to South Korea was leaked after unknown hackers gained access to the database of South Korea’s resettlement agency.

Title: Mustang Panda
Description: This threat actor targets nongovernmental organizations using Mongolian-themed lures for espionage purposes.

Title: Compromise of the Court of Arbitration for Sport
Affiliations: Believed to be the work of APT 28
Description: A threat actor compromised the Court of Arbitration for Sport. Seven of the individuals alleged to be behind this incident, believed to be Russian military intelligence (known as GRU), were indicted by the U.S. Justice Department.

Title: Targeting of a chemical plant in Ukraine
Affiliations: Believed to be the work of the same threat actors behind the alleged Russian compromise of networking equipment
Description: A threat actor used a tool called VPNFilter to target a chemical plant in eastern Ukraine that provides chlorine to water- and sewage-treatment plants in that country. Ukraine’s intelligence service claims to have thwarted the incident.

Title: Targeting of Mexican journalists’ mobile devices
Affiliations: Believed to be the work of the Mexican government.
Description: The Mexican government is suspected of using spyware to infiltrate journalists’ messages.

Title: Iron Tiger
Description: This threat actor targets governments as well as technology, education, and telecommunications companies primarily in Asia and the United States, for the purpose of espionage.
Victims: United States, Canada, Australia, Japan, China, Republic of Korea, Taiwan, Thailand, Russia, India, Israel, Iran

Title: Targeting of financial and chemical organizations in Europe
Affiliations: Believed to be the work of the same actors behind the compromise of the 2018 Winter Olympics
Description: A threat actor uses a tool, called Olympics Destroyer, to target financial organizations in Russia and biological and chemical laboratories in Ukraine and other countries in Europe.
Victims: Russia, France, The Netherlands, Switzerland, Germany, Ukraine

Title: Targeting of the personal email accounts of U.S. Senators and staff
Description: A threat actor targeted the personal email accounts of U.S. senators and staffers, according to Senator Ron Wyden (D-OR) and an unnamed technology company.

Title: Compromise of Australian National University
Description: A threat actor has compromised the network of Australian National University for espionage purposes.

Title: Compromise of the Canadian Centre for Ethics in Sport
Affiliations: Believed to be the work of APT 28
Description: A threat actor compromised the Canadian Centre for Ethics in Sport. Seven of the individuals alleged to be behind this incident, believed to be Russian military intelligence (known as GRU), were indicted by the U.S. Justice Department. Canada issued a statement attributing the incident to Russian military intelligence.
Victims: Canadian Centre for Ethics in Sport

Title: Targeting of emails of German lawmakers, military officials, and embassy staff
Affiliations: Believed to be the work of Russian hacker group Snake.
Description: German security officials detected a cyberattack, believed to be by the Russian group Snake, on the email accounts of German celebrities, lawmakers, military officials, and staff of several German embassies.

Title: Compromise of the Dukes
Description: A threat actor successfully compromised the networks of the Dukes, gaining visibility into the Dukes’ targeting methods and operations. This compromise allegedly helped the U.S. intelligence community to attribute the 2016 compromise of the Democratic National Committee and other entities to Russian state-sponsored actors.

Title: Targeting of chemical research and media organizations in Germany
Affiliations: Believed to be the work of the Black Energy threat actor.
Description: A threat actor targets German media companies and organizations involved in chemical weapons research, for the purpose of espionage.

Title: Poison Ivy
Description: This threat actor targets government and private-sector entities in the defense, maritime, and science and technology sectors in China for espionage purposes. It is particularly interested in information related to cross–Taiwan Strait and U.S.-Sino relations.

Title: HenBox
Description: This threat actor targets Uighurs—a minority ethnic group located primarily in northwestern China—and devices from Chinese mobile phone manufacturer Xiaomi, for espionage purposes.

Title: Compromise of FIFA
Affiliations: Believed to be the work of APT 28
Description: A threat actor compromised the Federation Internationale de Football Association (FIFA). Seven of the individuals alleged to be behind this incident, believed to be Russian military intelligence (known as GRU), were indicted by the U.S. Justice Department.

Title: Stealth Mango and Tangelo
Description: This threat actor, which consists of Stealth Mango (Android) and Tangelo (iOS), targets government officials, diplomats, military personnel, and activists in primarily Afghanistan, India, Iraq, Pakistan, and the United Arab Emirates for espionage.
Victims: Pakistan, Afghanistan, India, Iraq, United Arab Emirates, United States, Australia, Germany

Title: Targeting of the office of U.S. Senator Claire McCaskill
Affiliations: Believed to be the work of APT 28
Description: The office of U.S. Senator Claire McCaskill (D-MO) announced that it was targeted by Russian state-sponsored cyber actors, following a report of the incident in the Daily Beast.

Title: Compromise of Marriott International
Affiliations: Suspected to be the work of Chinese operatives working for the Ministry of State Security.
Description: Marriott reported a massive data breach that affected up to five hundred million customers in its Starwood hotels reservation system. U.S. private investigators believe China is behind the hack.

Title: Compromise of computer networks associated with the 2018 Pyeongchang Winter Olympics
Description: A threat actor, using a tool called Olympic Destroyer, successfully disrupted computer networks associated with the 2018 Winter Olympics in Pyeongchang, South Korea, before the opening ceremony. Among other things, the incident crashed the Wi-Fi network in the Olympic stadium and the press center.

Title: Thrip
Description: This threat actor targets organizations in the satellite communications, telecommunications, geospatial-imaging, and defense sectors in the United States and Southeast Asia for espionage purposes.

Title: Cobalt Dickens
Affiliations: Also known as the Silent Librarian. Believed to be associated with the Mabna Institute.
Description: This threat actor targets universities around the world for espionage purposes.
Victims: Australia, Canada, China, Israel, Japan, Switzerland, Turkey, United Kingdom, United States

Title: Targeting of a Swiss federal agency
Affiliations: Believed to be the work of Turla
Description: A threat actor targeted servers controlled by the Swiss Federal Department of Defense, Civil Protection, and Sports.

Title: Bad Rabbit
Affiliations: Believed to be the work of APT 28
Description: Using a tool called Bad Rabbit, a threat actor launched a ransomware operation that encrypted data on networks in Bulgaria, Japan, Russia, Turkey, and Ukraine. The operation is believed to have disrupted the Kiev metro system's payment network and delayed flights at Odessa's airport. In October 2018, the United Kingdom attributed this incident to Russian military intelligence.

Title: MuddyWater
Affiliations: Also known as TEMP.Zagros and Seedworm.
Description: This threat actor targets governments, primarily in the Middle East and South Asia, for espionage purposes.
Victims: Saudi Arabia, Iraq, United Arab Emirates, Georgia, Israel, Pakistan, Turkey, India, United States

Title: Compromise of the International Association of Athletics Federations
Affiliations: Believed to be the work of APT 28.
Description: A threat actor compromises the networks of the International Association of Athletics Federations with the purpose of obtaining the medical records of athletes. In October 2018, the United States indicted seven alleged Russian military intelligence officials involved in the incident.

Title: Targeting of certain individuals in Panama
Description: A threat actor targeted individuals who were political critics and business rivals of Ricardo Martinelli, president of Panama between 2009 and 2014, for espionage purposes. The threat actor uses the Pegasus tool, created by the NSO Group.

Title: Compromise of Far Eastern International Bank
Affiliations: Believed to be the work of the Lazarus Group
Description: A threat actor compromised the networks of Far Eastern International Bank in Taiwan, allowing them to transfer US$60 million to accounts based in the United States, Cambodia, and Sri Lanka using the SWIFT network.

Title: Compromise of email accounts of a UK TV station
Affiliations: Believed to be the work of APT 28
Description: A threat actor compromised Islam Channel, a small UK TV station, in July 2015. In October 2018, the United Kingdom publicly attributed the compromise to Russian military intelligence.

Title: APT 40
Affiliations: Also known as TEMP.Periscope, Leviathan, and Mudcarp. Believed to be behind the compromise of Cambodia’s election organizations and the Target of universities' maritime military secrets.
Description: This threat actor targets defense contractors, law firms, engineering firms, shipping companies, and government agencies with responsibilities or business in the maritime industry.
Victims: United States, The Philippines, Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation, Hong Kong

Title: NotPetya
Affiliations: Possibly linked to the same threat actors who designed Black Energy
Description: Threat actors deploy a tool, called NotPetya, with the purpose of encrypting data on victims' machines and rendering it unusable. The malware was spread through tax software that companies and individuals require for filing taxes in Ukraine. Australia, Estonia, Denmark, Lithuania, Ukraine, the United Kingdom, and the United States issued statements attributing NotPetya to Russian state-sponsored actors. In June 2018, the United States sanctioned Russian organizations believed to have assisted the Russian state-sponsored actors with the operation.
Victims: Rosneft, WPP Plc., Maersk, Cie de Saint-Gobain, SNCF, Merck, Mondelez, Port of Rosario, Kyivenergo, The government of Ukraine

Title: JadeRAT
Affiliations: Possibly linked to APT 30
Description: This threat actor, using a tool called JadeRAT, targets the mobile phones of ethnic minorities in China, notably Uighurs, for the purpose of espionage.

Title: Bronze Butler
Affiliations: Also known as Tick and RedBaldKnight
Description: This threat actor targets organizations in the critical infrastructure, heavy industry, manufacturing, and international relations sectors for espionage purposes.
Victims: Japan, Korea (Republic of), Russian Federation, China

Title: Indictment of APT 3 threat actors
Description: The U.S. Department of Justice indicted three members of Boyusec, a China-based internet security firm, on charges including conspiring to commit computer fraud and abuse and conspiring to commit trade-secret theft. The victims included Moody’s Analytics, Siemens, and Trimble. Though not mentioned in the indictment, Boyusec is believed to work on behalf of China’s Ministry of State Security.

Title: APT 10
Affiliations: Also known as Cloud Hopper, Red Apollo, CNVX, Stone Panda, MenuPass, and POTASSIUM. Believed to be a part of the Tianjin bureau of the Chinese Ministry of State Security.
Description: This threat actor targets managed information technology service providers to access client information for espionage purposes. APT 10 has been active since at least 2009.
Victims: Japan, United States, United Kingdom, India, Canada, Brazil, South Africa, Australia, Thailand, South Korea, France, Switzerland, Sweden, Finland, Norway, New Zealand

Title: Compromise of Kaspersky Labs
Affiliations: Believed to be the work of the same threat actors who used the Duqu 2.0 tool.
Description: A threat actor, believed to be the Israeli government, compromised Kaspersky Labs, a Russia-based cybersecurity company. The compromise of Kaspersky allegedly led Israeli intelligence to tip off U.S. officials that a former contractor had classified data from the National Security Agency on his home computer.

Title: APT 34
Affiliations: Possibly linked to OilRig
Description: This threat actor targets organizations in the financial, energy, government, chemical, and telecommunications sectors in the Middle East for the purpose of espionage.

Title: Targeting of the government of Belarus
Affiliations: Possibly linked to NetTraveler
Description: A threat actor targeted the government of Belarus for espionage purposes, using a tool known as Travle or PYLOT, which is believed to be an update of malware used by NetTraveler.

Title: Targeting of Chinese-language news websites
Affiliations: Believed to be the work of Winnti Umbrella
Description: A threat actor targeted the China Digital Times, a civil-society and news organization based outside China that publishes English- and Chinese-language content, using phishing techniques with the goal of compromising its network.

Title: Attempted compromise of email accounts associated with the UK Parliament
Description: A threat actor attempted to gain access to email accounts associated with members and other staffers of the British Parliament. The incident, originally believed to be the work of Russian or North Korean actors, was later attributed to Iran.

Title: CopyKittens
Description: This threat actor targets government institutions, universities, defense contractors, and large IT companies for the purpose of espionage.
Victims: Israel, Saudi Arabia, United States, Jordan, Germany

Title: Compromise of the Czech foreign minister's computer
Affiliations: APT 28
Description: A threat actor compromised the computer networks of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the Czech Republic, including those used by the foreign minister and close aides.

Title: Sowbug
Description: This threat actor targets government organizations with a foreign policy role primarily in Latin America for espionage purposes. The threat actor uses the tools Felismus and Starloader.
Victims: Argentina, Brazil, Peru, Ecuador, Brunei, Malaysia

Title: Targeting of U.S. electric companies
Description: A threat actor targeted U.S. electric companies with spear-phishing emails in an attempt to gain access to internal networks.

Title: Compromise of Qatari website, leading to diplomatic rift
Description: Qatar claims the website of the Qatar News Agency was compromised by an unknown actor, who posted false remarks attributed to the Emir of Qatar that expressed support for Iran, Israel, Hezbollah and Hamas. The Washington Post reports that U.S. intelligence officials have identified the unknown actor as the United Arab Emirates.

Title: Targeting of the citizen journalism website Bellingcat
Affiliations: Believed to be the work of APT 28
Description: A threat actor attempted to compromise Bellingcat, a citizen journalism website that conducts investigations, including about Russian involvement in the Syrian and Ukrainian conflicts.

Title: WannaCry
Affiliations: Believed to be the work of the Lazarus Group.
Description:
A threat actor used a tool called WannaCry to encrypt data in compromised networks, and intended to provide the victims with the decryption key only after a ransom had been paid. The threat actors used an exploit, called EternalBlue--first discovered by the U.S. National Security Agency--to propagate WannaCry in organizations using the Windows operating system. On December 19, 2017, the United States, Australia, Canada, Japan, and the United Kingdom issued statements accusing North Korea of being responsible for WannaCry.

In September 2018, the U.S. Department of Justice announced criminal charges alleging that North Korean entities were responsible for this incident.
Victims: FedEx, UK National Health Service, Telefonica, Deutsche Bahn, PetroChina, Hitachi, Renault, Nissan, Sberbank

Title: APT 33
Affiliations: Also known as Magnallium
Description: This threat actor targets private-sector entities in the aviation, energy, and petrochemical sectors for the purpose of espionage.
Victims: United States, Saudi Arabia, South Korea

Title: Targeting of Ethiopian dissidents
Description: A threat actor targeted Ethiopian dissidents for the purpose of espionage, using commercially available spyware sold by Cyberbit, an Israel-based company. Cyberbit is also believed to have tried to sell its spyware to law enforcement and national security organizations in the Philippines, Thailand, Uzbekistan, and Zambia.

Title: Targeting North Korea's Reconnaissance General Bureau
Description: U.S. government officials told the Washington Post that the United States had launched a denial of service campaign against North Korea's Reconnaissance General Bureau, the country's intelligence agency.

Title: Distributed denial of service against the government of Montenegro
Description: A threat actor launched a distributed denial of service attack against government of Montenegro websites.

Title: Compromise of cryptocurrency exchanges in South Korea
Affiliations: Believed to be the work of a subset of the Lazarus Group known as Bluenoroff
Description: A threat actor targeted cryptocurrency exchanges in South Korea for the purpose of raising money.

Title: Compromise of Singapore's Ministry of Defense
Description: A threat actor compromised an internet-facing computer network in the Ministry of Defense of Singapore, compromising the personal data of approximately 850 servicemen and employees.

Title: Compromise the North Korean nuclear program
Description: A threat actor, believed to be the United States, targeted computer networks and electronic components associated with the North Korean nuclear program to sabotage and slow its development.

Title: Targeting of Marco Rubio's presidential campaign
Description: A threat actor targeted the presidential campaign of U.S. Senator Marco Rubio.
Victims: The 2016 presidential campaign of Marco Rubio

Title: Longhorn
Affiliations: Also known as the Lamberts
Description: This threat actor compromises governments, international organizations, academic institutions, and financial, telecommunications, energy, aerospace, information technology, and natural resource  industries for espionage purposes. Some of the tools used by this threat actor were released by Wikileaks under the name "Vault 7."

Title: Phishing campaign against Montenegro
Affiliations: Believed to be the work of APT 28
Description: A threat actor targeted officials from Montenegro for the purpose of espionage. The phishing campaign came during the country’s accession to NATO.

Title: Compromise of a Danish Ministry of Defense e-mail service
Affiliations: Believed to be the work of APT 28
Description: A threat actor compromised an email service maintained by the Danish Ministry of Defense, and is also believed to have compromised Ministry of Foreign Affairs networks.

Title: Targeting of French presidential candidate Emmanuel Macron's campaign
Affiliations: Believed to be the work of APT 28
Description: A threat actor targeted the campaign of French presidential candidate Emmanuel Macron. The U.S. National Security Agency has confirmed that it believes Russia was responsible.

Title: Magic Hound
Affiliations: Also known as Cobalt Gypsy and possibly associated with Rocket Kitten
Description: This threat actor targets entities in the government, energy, and technology sectors that are located in or do business with Saudi Arabia.

Title: WhiteBear
Affiliations: Associated with Turla
Description: This threat actor targets defense contractors and diplomatic institutions for the purpose of espionage.
Victims: United States, United Kingdom, Uzbekistan, South Korea

Title: Compromise of the Italian Ministry of Foreign Affairs
Description: A threat actor compromised the Italian Ministry of Foreign Affairs’ computer networks.

Title: Operation BugDrop
Description: This threat actor targets critical infrastructure entities in the oil and gas sector, primarily in Ukraine. The threat actors deploy the BugDrop malware to remotely access the microphones in their targets' computers to eavesdrop on conversations.

Title: Targeting of employees of companies that operate U.S. nuclear power plants
Description: A threat actor targeted employees of companies that operate nuclear power plants in the United States, which prompted the Department of Homeland Security and the FBI to issue an alert to the industry. An administrative network of the Wolf Creek Nuclear Operating Corporation was compromised.

Title: Attempted compromise of Norwegian government networks
Affiliations: Believed to be the work of the Dukes
Description: A threat actor targeted the computer networks of the Norwegian government: the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, the army, a nuclear radiation protection agency, and a parliamentary group.

Title: Compromise of Israeli Defense Force personnel
Description: A threat actor used a tool called ViperRAT to target Israeli Defense Force personnel and compromise devices running the Android operating system, allowing a remote actor to access the devices' video and audio capabilities as well as text message and location data.

Title: Mexico accused of targeting journalists and civil society groups
Description: A threat actor targets journalists, lawyers, and other civil society groups in Mexico using commercial malware, developed by the NSO Group, for the purpose of espionage.
Victims: Aristegui Noticias, Carlos Loret de Mola, Mexicans against Corruption and Impunity, Centro PRODH, Mexican Institute for Competitiveness

Title: Shamoon 2.0
Affiliations: Believed to have been partially the work of Chrysene
Description: A threat actor used malware known as Shamoon 2.0 to exfiltrate and delete data from computers in the Saudi transportation sector.
Victims: General Authority of Civil Aviation of Saudi Arabia

Title: SWIFT-related bank heists
Affiliations: Believed to be the work of Lazarus Group
Description:
A threat actor targets the worldwide financial transfer mechanism known as SWIFT to steal funds from banks in Bangladesh, Vietnam, Ecuador, and Poland. This is the first instance in where a state-sponsored actor was discovered to have compromised networks for financial gain.

In September 2018, the U.S. Department of Justice announced criminal charges alleging that North Korean entities were responsible for this incident.
Victims: Bangladesh Central Bank, Tien Phong Bank, Banco Del Austro, Poland

Title: Compromise of South Korean government computers (2016)
Description: A threat actor compromised computers associated with the South Korean Ministry of National Defense. In October 2017, South Korean officials confirmed that North Korea had exfiltrated over two hundred gigabytes of data from the defense ministry networks, including military plans the United States and South Korea would implement in the event of a war with North Korea.

Title: Denial of service incident against media websites in Sweden
Description: A threat actor launched a denial of service attack on ten news websites in Sweden, triggering a local police investigation. U.S. diplomatic cables later revealed that the United States suspected that Russia was responsible for the incident.

Title: Stealth Falcon
Description: This threat actor targets civil society groups and Emirati journalists, activists, and dissidents.

Title: Compromise of the Democratic National Committee
Affiliations: This incident is believed to be the work of APT 28. The Dukes were also found to be in the Democratic National Committee's networks.
Description:
In June 2016, suspected Russian threat actors were discovered in the networks of the U.S. Democratic National Committee (DNC). Intruders gained access to its research on Republican presidential candidate Donald J. Trump and emails and correspondences among DNC officials. Over the course of the presidential campaign, the threat actors released DNC correspondence through intermediaries such as WikiLeaks, revealing information about infighting among top party officials and leading to the resignation of the DNC chair. The threat actors also went after John Podesta, chairman of Hillary Clinton’s campaign, and released more embarrassing data throughout the summer.

The secretary of homeland security and the director of national intelligence released a joint statement asserting that the protracted cyber espionage campaign was the work of Russian actors. The Barack Obama administration subsequently sanctioned Russian intelligence officials and deported suspected officers working in the United States. The DNC compromise is believed to be part of a larger Russian espionage campaign waged for the purpose of manipulating the electoral systems in Western democracies and undermining faith in the democratic process in the United States, France, Germany, and elsewhere.

In July 2018, the U.S. Department of Justice indicted twelve officials of the Russian military intelligence agency, known as GRU, believed to have been responsible for this incident.

 

In October 2018, the UK government announced that the compromise was the work of Russian military intelligence.
Victims: Democratic National Committee, Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee

Title: OilRig
Affiliations: Also known as Twisted Kitten and Crambus; possibly related to Magic Hound, APT 34, and Chrysene. Believed to use similar tools and infrastructure as Chafer
Description: A threat actor believed to be Iran that targets private-sector and government entities for the purpose of espionage.
Victims: Israel, Turkey, Qatar, Kuwait, Saudi Arabia, Lebanon, United States

Title: Targeting of the Islamic State group
Affiliations: Believed to be associated with the United Kingdom’s cyber operations against the Islamic State, revealed in 2018.
Description: The United States announced that it would conduct offensive cyber operations against the Islamic State with a view to disrupting its ability to recruit, communicate with, and exercise command and control over its fighters.

Title: Compromise of the World Anti-Doping Agency
Affiliations: Believed to be the work of APT 28
Description:
The World Anti-Doping Agency (WADA) confirmed in September 2016 that it had been compromised by suspected Russian threat actors in a data leak of confidential information about forty-one athletes who competed in the Rio Olympic Games. The data revealed drug-test results and medical data pertaining to “therapeutic use exemptions,” situations in which WADA allows athletes to take banned substances if their usage is deemed legitimate.

A group using the Fancy Bear moniker, the same term some security experts assign to a Russian state-sponsored threat actor, claimed responsibility for the compromise. Some commentators viewed the incident as Russian retaliation for a WADA report that detailed Moscow-sanctioned efforts to provide performance-enhancing drugs to Russian athletes during the 2014 Sochi Winter Olympics.

The United States, Australia, Canada, New Zealand, and the United Kingdom issued statements attributing the incident to Russian military intelligence. Separately, the United States issued an indictment against seven alleged Russian military intelligence officials involved in the incident.

Title: Compromise of gaming companies
Affiliations: Believed to be the work of Winnti Umbrella
Description: A threat actor uses a tool called PassCV to target video game companies, stealing digital certificates to use in cyber operations against other targets.
Victims: China, Taiwan, South Korea, United States, Russia

Title: Yahoo breach (2014)
Affiliations: Same state sponsor as the 2016 breach
Description: A threat actor compromised over approximately five hundred million accounts, giving it access to the names, email addresses, telephone numbers, and dates of birth associated with the accounts. Yahoo discloses that the compromise took place in 2014.

Title: Spear-phishing campaign against Google accounts in 2015
Affiliations: Believed to be the work of APT 28
Description: A threat actor conducted a spear-phishing campaign against more than 1,800 Google accounts, including those of military and government personnel, journalists, and nongovernmental organizations, for the purpose of espionage.

Title: Lazarus Group
Affiliations: Believed to be responsible for Dark Seoul, Ten Days of Rain, the Sony Pictures Entertainment attack, the SWIFT-related bank heists, WannaCry, and Operation GhostSecret. Believed to use the same tools as Covellite. Known to the U.S. government as Hidden Cobra.
Description:
This threat actor targets and compromises entities primarily in South Korea and South Korean interests for espionage, disruption, and destruction. It has also been known to conduct cyber operations for financial gain, including targeting cryptocurrency exchanges. In 2018, the U.S. Department of Homeland Security issued a malware analysis report on a tool called Typeframe used by the Lazarus Group.

In September 2018, the U.S. Department of Justice criminally charged and sanctioned Park Jin-hyok and Chosun Expo Joint Venture, alleged members of this threat actor.
Victims: South Korea, Sony Pictures Entertainment , United States, Bangladesh Bank

Title: Prince of Persia
Description: This threat actor targets governments and businesses of multiple countries, including the United States, Israel, and Denmark.
Victims: Israel, United States, Denmark, Iran, United Kingdom, Canada, France, Germany, Russia, China, Syria, Saudi Arabia, Sweden, Italy, Bahrain

Title: Compromise of Burmese government websites
Description: A threat actor compromised Burmese websites in an attempt to compromise visitors to those websites for espionage purposes.

Title: Warning of impending incident on Russian banking network
Description: Russian authorities warned that a foreign intelligence agency was seeking to compromise its banking sector.

Title: Onion Dog
Affiliations: Possibly linked to Icefog and the Dark Seoul compromise
Description: This threat actor targets the South Korean government, transportation, and energy sectors.

Title: Mofang
Description: This threat actor compromises government and critical infrastructure entities, primarily in Myanmar, for espionage purposes.
Victims: Myanmar, Canada, United States, Germany, India, South Korea, Singapore

Title: RUAG espionage
Affiliations: Believed to be the work of the Turla group
Description: A threat actor compromised a Swiss defense contractor.

Title: Compromise of Ukrainian banks
Affiliations: Believed to be the work of the actors behind Black Energy
Description: A threat actor compromised Ukrainian banks.

Title: Operation Mermaid
Description: This threat actor is based in the Middle East (possibly Iran) and targets English- and Persian-language organizations. It is alleged to be the same group behind a compromise of the Danish Ministry of Foreign Affairs.

Title: Yahoo breach (2016)
Affiliations: Same state sponsor as the 2014 breach
Description: A threat actor exploited a vulnerability in Yahoo's account log-in process, allowing it to access user accounts without a password. Approximately thirty-two million accounts were affected.

Title: Project Sauron
Affiliations: Also known as Strider
Description: This threat actor compromises targets in the Military, telecommunications, and financial sectors in Belgium, China, Iran, Russia, Sweden, and elsewhere.
Victims: Russia, Belgium, Sweden, Iran, China, Rwanda

Title: Compromise of entities involved in the China-Philippines territorial dispute
Description: A threat actor targeted the Department of Justice of the Philippines, the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC), and a major international law firm representing one of the parties in the dispute over the Scarborough Shoal.

Title: A compromise causes a power outage in Kiev, Ukraine
Affiliations: Used an evolution of the tools developed by the team behind Black Energy.
Description: A threat actor compromised computer networks that control an electricity substation in the north of the Ukrainian capital, Kiev, causing a power outage. To accomplish its task, the threat actor used a tool known as CrashOverride.

Title: Operation Sphinx
Description: This threat actor targets government and military organizations in Egypt and Israel for espionage purposes.

Title: Compromise of computer networks associated with diplomats, journalists, and others in South Korea
Description: Threat actors targeted the email accounts of South Korean diplomats, journalists, and security officials.

Title: Compromise of a mobile app used by Ukrainian artillery units
Affiliations: Believed to be the work of APT 28
Description: A threat actor compromised a mobile app that Ukrainian artillery units used to assist with targeting. The compromise of the app is believed to have allowed the threat actor to monitor the movements of Ukrainian units in order to facilitate military targeting by Russian-backed rebels in eastern Ukraine.

Title: APT 16
Description: This threat actor targets and compromises Japanese and Taiwanese entities in the finance, tech, media, and government sectors.

Title: Targeting of Kazakh dissidents
Description: Threat actors targeted lawyers and exiled Kazakh dissidents for the purpose of espionage.

Title: Attempted compromise of U.S. think tanks
Affiliations: Believed to be the work of the Dukes
Description: A threat actor attempted to compromise the networks of U.S. think tanks associated with international affairs and national security. The attempts occurred shortly after the U.S. election in 2016.
Victims: Council on Foreign Relations, Brookings Institution

Title: Unnamed Actor
Description: This threat actor compromises civil society groups the Chinese Communist Party views as hostile to its interests, such as Tibetan, Uyghur, Hong Kong, and Taiwanese activist. The threat actor also targeted the Myanmar electoral commission.

Title: APT 30
Affiliations: Also known as Naikon, PLA Unit 78020, Lotus Panda. Possibly responsible for the JadeRAT tool.
Description: This threat actor uses spear-phishing techniques to target government and private sector agencies in the South China Sea region.
Victims: India, Thailand, South Korea, Saudi Arabia, Malaysia, United States, Vietnam, Cambodia, Indonesia, Myanmar, China, Laos, Singapore, Phillipines

Title: Compromise of Anthem
Affiliations: Believed to be the work of Deep Panda
Description: A threat actor compromised a U.S. health insurance company, resulting in compromised personal data on eighty million customers.

Title: Ocean Lotus
Affiliations: Also known as APT 32
Description: This threat actor, known to use watering-hole attacks to compromise victims, targets organizations of interest to the Vietnamese government for espionage purposes. Victims have included human rights organizations, research institutes and maritime construction firms in China, and media organizations. Also believed to have been responsible for disclosing confidential Filipino government documents.
Victims: China, United States, Philippines, Germany, Vietnam, Association of Southeast Asian Nations, Cambodia, Laos

Title: Goblin Panda
Description: This threat actor targets government agencies and entities in the defense and energy sectors in Southeast Asia with an interest in issues related to tensions in the South China Sea.

Title: Gamaredon
Affiliations: Also known as the Gamaredon Group.
Description: A Russian-linked threat group known as Gamaredon uses custom-developed malware in attacks aimed at Ukraine. The group has been active since at least 2013.

Title: Duqu 2.0
Affiliations: Associated with Duqu. Believed to have been the tool used to compromise Kaspersky Labs.
Description: A threat actor, using a tool dubbed Duqu 2.0, targeted individuals and companies linked to the P5+1 (the five permanent member states of the UN Security Council, plus Germany), which was conducting negotiations on Iran's nuclear program.

Title: Chafer
Affiliations: Believed to use similar tools and infrastructure as OilRig
Description: This threat actor targets organizations in the aerospace, technology, telecommunications, and engineering sectors for the purpose of espionage.
Victims: Saudi Arabia, United Arab Emirates, Israel, Jordan, Turkey

Title: APT 3
Affiliations: Also known as UPS, Gothic Panda, Buckeye, and Boyusec
Description: This threat actor targets and compromises entities in the defense, construction, technology, and transportation sectors. Up until 2015, it was primarily focused on U.S. and UK entities, but it shifted to Hong Kong–based targets afterward. The U.S. Department of Justice indicted three members of this threat actor group in November 2017 for compromising the networks of three U.S. companies.
Victims: United States, United Kingdom, Hong Kong

Title: Emissary Panda
Affiliations: Also known as TG-3390, APT 27, and TEMP.Hippo. Believed to have been responsible for the compromise of a Mongolian data center.
Description: This threat actor compromises web pages to lure targets for espionage purposes. It focuses on the aerospace, automotive, technology, and energy sectors, primarily in the United States and United Kingdom.

Title: Compromise of TV5 Monde
Affiliations: Suspected to be the work of APT 28
Description:
In May 2015, threat actors compromised French television network TV5 Monde, disrupting broadcasts for three hours and gaining access to the network’s social media accounts. A group allegedly allied with the self-declared Islamic State and calling itself the Cyber Caliphate initially claimed responsibility for the incident. However, later investigations revealed links to Russian hacking group APT 28.

TV5 Monde is an example of a “false flag” operation, whereby a threat actor tries to mask its identity by leaving clues or attributes that would cause the victim to pin the blame on someone else. The threat actors behind TV5 Monde were successful enough in their flagging to lead French authorities to believe the incident was a terrorist attack. It is unknown why Russia would have conducted a false flag operation in France disguising itself as the Islamic State. 

In October 2018, the UK government announced that this incident was the work of Russian military intelligence.

Title: Targeting of the government of Thailand
Affiliations: Believed to be the work of Winnti Umbrella
Description: A threat actor used a tool called Bookworm to compromise government agencies in Thailand, for the purpose of espionage.

Title: APT 17
Affiliations: Also known as Deputy Dog. Believed to be associated with Winnti Umbrella
Description: This threat actor targets U.S. government entities, the defense industrial base, law firms, information technology companies, resource extraction companies, and nongovernmental organizations.

Title: Rocket Kitten
Affiliations: Possibly linked to Saffron Rose
Description: This threat actor targets defense contractors and academic institutions in Israel, European government agencies, and civil society actors. It seeks out material related to diplomacy, defense, security, journalism, and human rights for espionage purposes.
Victims: Saudi Arabia, Israel, Yemen, Venezuela, Iraq, United Kingdom, Afghanistan, Kuwait, Egypt, United Arab Emirates, Turkey, Syria, Iran, Canada, Jordan

Title: Equation Group
Affiliations: Also known as Tilded Team, it is associated with Flame, Stuxnet, Regin, Gauss, and Duqu.
Description:
In 2015, Moscow-based Kaspersky Lab published a report on the Equation Group, a threat actor active since 2001 [PDF]. It was responsible for infecting approximately five hundred systems in at least forty-two countries. The malware used by Equation Group had the ability to reprogram hard drives and then self-destruct, which made the operations effectively invisible and indestructible. Targeted systems ranged from the private to the public sector, from energy departments to military operations to media outlets.

The tools and scope of the Equation Group suggest that it is one of the most sophisticated threat actors operating in cyberspace. Many believe that Equation Group is a state-sponsored entity, such as the U.S. National Security Agency or a joint effort between it and its Five Eyes allies.
Victims: Iran, Russia, Pakistan, Afghanistan, India, China, Syria, Mali, Lebanon, Yemen, Algeria, United Arab Emirates, Kenya, United Kingdom, Libya

Title: Compromise of a Pentagon legacy system
Affiliations: Suspected to be the work of the Dukes
Description: A threat actor compromised a legacy unclassified network at the Department of Defense.

Title: Compromise at the Office of Personnel Management
Affiliations: Suspected to be the work of Deep Panda
Description: A threat actor compromised the networks of the U.S. Office of Personnel Management, exposing the data of at least 22.1 million people who have applied for a U.S. security clearance.

Title: Hellsing
Affiliations: Possibly uses the same infrastructure as Mirage
Description: This threat actor uses spear-phishing techniques to compromise diplomatic targets in Southeast Asia, India, and the United States. It also seems to have targeted the APT 30.
Victims: Malaysia, Philippines, India, Indonesia, United States

Title: Compromise of an unclassified network associated with the U.S. Joint Chiefs of Staff
Affiliations: Believed to be the work of APT 28
Description: A threat actor compromised an unclassified network used by the U.S. Joint Chiefs of Staff for espionage purposes.

Title: Compromise of United Airlines
Affiliations: Suspected to be the work of Deep Panda
Description: A threat actor compromised the network of United Airlines for espionage purposes, gaining access to flight manifests.

Title: Targeting of Ukrainian law enforcement and government officials
Description: A threat actor attempted to compromise Ukrainian officials in government and law enforcement for espionage purposes. Ukrainian intelligence claims this was done in support of Russian-backed military activities in eastern Ukraine.

Title: Compromise of the Seoul subway system
Affiliations: Believed to be the work of the same actors behind Dark Seoul and possibly linked to Onion Dog
Description: A threat actor compromised networks associated with Seoul's subway system.

Title: Disruption of GitHub
Description: A threat actor launched a denial of service attack against GitHub to prevent access to internet content banned in China, such as the New York Times. The incident was the first in which threat actors, believed to be associated with the government of China, used a tool dubbed the Great Cannon.

Title: Compromise of the Permanent Court of Arbitration's website
Description: A threat actor compromised the website of the Permanent Course of Arbitration for espionage purposes, intending to compromise visitors to the website.

Title: Compromise of unclassified White House networks
Affiliations: Suspected to be the work of the Dukes
Description: Threat actors compromised unclassified White House networks using access from compromised networks at the State Department.
Victims: White House, U.S Department of State

Title: Compromise of South Korean government computers (2015)
Description: A threat actor compromised government networks affiliated with members of the South Korean parliament. The threat actor also attempted to compromise the Foreign Ministry, Defense Ministry, and the Blue House.

Title: Blue Termite
Affiliations: This threat actor is believed to have been responsible for the Japan Pension Service incident. It is also known as Emdivi and Cloudy Omega.
Description: This threat actor targets Japanese entities in the government, manufacturing, finance, space, education, food, and medical sectors for espionage purposes.

Title: Attempted compromise of the Dutch organization investigating the crash of flight MH17
Affiliations: Possibly attributed to APT 28
Description: A threat actor attempted to compromise the networks of the Dutch Safety Board, the group charged with investigating the crash of Malaysia Airlines Flight 17, which crashed in Ukraine.

Title: Compromise of networks in the Saudi government ministries
Affiliations: Believed to be the work of Saffron Rose
Description: A threat actor compromised the networks of several Saudi government ministries for the purposes of espionage and doxing.
Victims: Ministry of Foreign Affairs, Ministry of the Interior, Ministry of Defense

Title: Compromise of social media accounts of State Department officials
Description: A threat actor compromised social media accounts of junior State Department staff to launch spear-phishing campaigns for espionage purposes.

Title: Compromise of the networks at the German parliament (Bundestag)
Affiliations: Believed to be the work of APT 28
Description: A threat actor compromised the networks of the German parliament for the purpose of espionage.

Title: Network compromise at the Australian Bureau of Meteorology
Description: A threat actor compromised the networks of Australia's Bureau of Meteorology for espionage purposes.

Title: Compromise of the Japanese pension system
Affiliations: Linked to Blue Termite
Description: A threat actor compromised the networks of the Japan Pension Service and gained access to the pension records of over 1.25 million individuals.

Title: Compromise of a power grid in eastern Ukraine
Affiliations: Possible link to Black Energy
Description:
In December 2015, a threat actor compromised power distribution companies in western Ukraine, causing a power outage for more than 230,000 residents. Several control centers were targeted by suspected Russian hackers, who were able to siphon operator credentials and gain access to the power grid for the Ivano-Frankivsk region. The power outage lasted as long as six hours in some areas. During the outage, threat actors also flooded customer services phone lines with calls to prevent customers from reporting the incident.

The compromise of the Ukrainian power grid was an escalation from previous disruptive incidents and the first confirmed cyber operation to successfully take down energy infrastructure. The incident set an ominous precedent for the security of power grids around the world. The electricity distribution system in Ukraine was again targeted in 2016.

Title: Crouching Yeti
Affiliations: Also known as Energetic Bear, Dragonfly, Group 24, and Koala Team. Possibly associated with Allanite and Dymalloy. Believed to be behind the targeting of critical infrastructure entities in the United States and Germany, prompting both countries to issue technical alerts
Description: This threat actor targets companies in the education, energy, construction, information technology, and pharmaceutical sectors for the purposes of espionage. It uses malware tailored to target industrial control systems.
Victims: United States, Spain, Japan, Germany, France, Italy, Turkey, Ireland, Poland, China, Russia, Ukraine, United Kingdom, Greece

Title: DragonOK
Affiliations: Uses similar tools as Moafee and Rancor, possibly indicating a link between the threat actors
Description: This threat actor targets high-tech and manufacturing companies, primarily from Japan, for the purpose of acquiring trade secrets. In 2017, cybersecurity firms released evidence pointing to the threat actor expanding its targets to Russian and Tibetan interests.

Title: Compromise of U.S. Transportation Command Contractors
Description: A threat actor successfully compromises the networks of contractors for U.S. Transportation Command (TRANSCOM), a military command assigned with moving U.S. military personnel and assets around the world.

Title: Turla
Affiliations: Turla is also known as Snake, Venomous Bear, Uroburos, Group 88, Waterbug, and Turla Team. Estonian intelligence services associate this group with the Russian federal security service (FSB). Turla is associated with Agent.btz and believed to be behind the RUAG espionage incident, an attempted compromise of the Swiss defense ministry, the targeting of diplomatic missions in Eastern Europe, the targeting of South Korean actors prior to the meeting of U.S. President Donald J. Trump and North Korean leader Kim Jong-un, and the compromise of the German and Finnish foreign ministries.
Description: This threat actor targets governments, militaries, and research organizations for espionage purposes.
Victims: France, Russia, Belarus, Romania, United States, Netherlands, Kazakhstan, Saudi Arabia, Iran, Poland, Germany, Uzbekistan, Tajikistan, India, Iraq

Title: Moafee
Affiliations: Uses similar tools as DragonOK, possibly indicating a link between the two
Description: This threat actor targets militaries and governments interested in the South China Sea, including the U.S. defense industrial base.

Title: Compromise of Sony Pictures Entertainment
Affiliations: Believed to be the work of the Lazarus Group
Description:
Threat actors compromised the networks of Sony Pictures Entertainment, destroyed data, and publicly released employee emails. The United States attributed the incident to North Korea, which is believed to have staged the attack to prevent Sony from releasing the film The Interview, which depicts an assassination plot against North Korean leader Kim Jong-un.

The compromise of Sony Pictures was the first cyber incident to be formally condemned by a U.S. president. The incident also prompted the United States to sanction certain North Korean individuals and organizations, denying them access to U.S. financial institutions.

In September 2018, the U.S. Department of Justice announced criminal charges alleging that North Korean entities were responsible for this incident.

Title: Axiom
Affiliations: Also known as Winnti Group. Believed to be associated with Winnti Umbrella
Description: This threat actor compromises a range of actors of espionage purposes, namely government agencies in Asia and the West, circuit manufacturers, networking equipment manufacturers, internet companies, software vendors, journalists, nongovernmental organizations, law firms, telecommunication firms, venture capitalists, and academic institutions.
Victims: United States, United Kingdom, Germany, Netherlands, Belgium, Switzerland, Italy, Russia, China, Japan, Indonesia

Title: APT 28
Affiliations:
Also known as Pawn Storm, Fancy Bear, Sofacy, Tsar Team, Strontium, and Sednit. Estonian and British intelligence services associate this group with Russian military intelligence (GRU). The United States believes that GRU units 26165 and 74455 form a part of this threat actor. 

Suspected to be behind the Democratic National Committee compromise, the 2015 compromise of networks of the German Bundestag, the 2015 TV5 Monde incident, the UK TV station incident, the hacking of a Ukrainian military mobile app, the compromise of the World Anti-Doping Agency, the compromise of numerous sports federations, the attempted compromise of Bellingcat, the Bad Rabbit incident, the targeting of European foreign ministries and defense agencies, the targeting of campaigns for the 2018 U.S. midterm elections, the targeting of the office of Senator Claire McCaskill, the targeting of the OPCW, and the compromise of U.S. Anti-Doping Agency, the Court of Arbitration for Sport, the Canadian Centre for Ethics in Sport, FIFA, and Westinghouse.
Description: This threat actor is linked to espionage campaigns, high-profile doxing efforts, and disruptive incidents that compromised targets believed to be of interest to the Russian government.
Victims: Georgia, NATO, OSCE, France, Ukraine, United Kingdom, Jordan, Belgium, Germany, United States, Pakistan, Poland, Hungary, Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation, European Commission, World Anti-Doping Agency, International Association of Athletics Federations, Afghanistan, Armenia, Turkey, Kazakhstan, Tajikistan, Mongolia, China, Japan, Canada, Organization for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons, Court of Arbitration for Sport, Federation Internationale de Football Association

Title: Black Energy
Affiliations: Also known as Sandworm, Voodoo Bear, and Electrum. Believed to be responsible for the 2008 DDoS attacks in Georgia and the 2015 Ukraine power grid outage. Code used by this threat actor was also found in the alleged Russian compromise of networking equipment. There is possible overlap between Black Energy and the threat actor behind the compromise of the 2018 Winter Olympics.
Description:
This threat actor targets industrial control systems, using a tool called Black Energy, associated with electricity and power generation for espionage, denial of service, and data destruction purposes. Some believe that the threat actor is linked to the 2015 compromise of the Ukrainian electrical grid and a distributed denial of service prior to the Russian invasion of Georgia. 

In 2018, Germany’s domestic intelligence agency released a technical alert about this threat actor, and the United Kingdom attributed the actor to Russian military intelligence.
Victims: Russia, Ukraine, Poland, Lithuania, Belarus, Azerbaijan, Kyrgyzstan, Kazakhstan, Iran, Israel, Georgia

Title: Newscaster
Affiliations: Also known as Charming Kitten and Group 83. Possibly linked to Rocket Kitten
Description: This threat actor uses watering hole attacks and fake profiles to lure targets from the U.S. government for espionage purposes. Also believed to target scholars who study Iran, human rights organizations, and the media. At least one cybersecurity company claims that Behzah Mesri, who was indicted by the U.S. Department of Justice for compromising the networks of HBO, was a member of this threat actor group
Victims: U.S. government/defense sector websites, Israel, United Kingdom, Saudi Arabia, Iraq

Title: APT 18
Affiliations: Also known as Dynamite Panda and TG-0416
Description: This threat actor targets human rights groups, government entities, and companies in the pharmaceutical, medical, industrial, and information technology sectors.
